title: Quiz 8: ENT (Ear, Nose, Throat)
topicName: NCK Paper 1 Anatomy and Physiology Questions
description: ENT Nursing MCQs covering sinusitis, otitis, vertigo, epistaxis, and neck masses.

questions.question: A patient presents with unilateral nasal congestion, facial pain, and purulent nasal discharge. Upon examination, tenderness is noted over the affected sinus. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: The classic triad for acute bacterial sinusitis includes purulent nasal discharge, facial pain/pressure/tenderness, and nasal obstruction. The unilaterality and tenderness over the sinus strongly point to an acute infectious process.
questions.hint: Purulent discharge and tenderness suggest infection.

questions.question: A patient presents with hoarseness, dysphonia, and occasional throat pain. Direct laryngoscopy reveals vocal cord nodules. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate for managing this condition?

options.text: Voice therapy and vocal hygiene education

questions.explanation: Vocal nodules (Singer's nodules) are typically caused by vocal abuse or misuse. The first-line treatment is conservative management through speech/voice therapy to correct the underlying behavior.
questions.hint: This condition is often caused by 'misuse' of the voice.

questions.question: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo, nausea, and nystagmus, often triggered by head movements. Dix-Hallpike maneuver elicits positional vertigo and rotary nystagmus. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: BPPV is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo triggered by changes in head position. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is the diagnostic test of choice.
questions.hint: The symptoms are triggered specifically by head movement.

questions.question: A patient presents with severe sore throat, fever, and enlarged tonsils with exudate. Rapid antigen testing confirms group A beta-hemolytic Streptococcus (GAS) infection. Which of the following medications is the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation: Penicillin V or Amoxicillin is the first-line antibiotic treatment for Strep Throat (GAS) to prevent complications like Rheumatic Fever.
questions.hint: This penicillin-based drug is standard for Strep throat.

questions.question: A patient presents with sudden onset of severe, unilateral ear pain, diminished hearing, and purulent otorrhea. Otoscopic examination reveals a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with obscured landmarks. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: A bulging, red tympanic membrane with acute pain is the hallmark of Acute Otitis Media (AOM). Otorrhea implies perforation.
questions.hint: Infection of the middle ear causing the eardrum to bulge.

questions.question: A patient presents with a painless, gradually enlarging mass in the left neck, anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Fine-needle aspiration cytology reveals thyroid follicular cells. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: Although typically midline, a Thyroglossal duct cyst contains thyroid remnants (follicular cells). Finding thyroid cells in a neck mass outside the thyroid bed suggests this developmental anomaly.
questions.hint: A developmental cyst containing thyroid tissue.

questions.question: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of epistaxis, particularly after blowing the nose or during dry weather. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals a friable, vascular lesion in Little's area. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate for managing this condition?

options.text: Nasal packing with anterior nasal tampons
Endoscopic cauterization of the sphenopalatine artery
Surgical excision of the nasal polyp

questions.explanation: For a visible, anterior bleeding source (Little's Area) that is not actively spurting, chemical cautery with silver nitrate is a first-line office procedure.
questions.hint: Chemical cauterization is suitable for visible anterior bleeds.

questions.question: A patient presents with progressive hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo. Audiometric testing reveals sensorineural hearing loss with a 'carrot-shaped' (peaked) configuration. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: The classic triad of Ménière's disease is Vertigo, Tinnitus, and Hearing Loss. The audiogram typically shows a specific curve often described in exams as 'carrot-shaped' or rising.
questions.hint: Triad of Vertigo, Tinnitus, and Hearing Loss.

questions.question: A patient presents with a palpable, non-tender mass in the right neck, just below the angle of the mandible. Ultrasound imaging demonstrates a well-defined, hypoechoic lesion with cystic components. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: A Second Branchial Cleft Cyst typically presents as a painless mass anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle, below the angle of the mandible.
questions.hint: A congenital cyst located laterally in the neck.

questions.question: A patient presents with a sudden onset of severe vertigo, nausea, vomiting, and nystagmus. The patient reports a recent upper respiratory tract infection. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: The association with a recent viral URI and the 'sudden severe' nature without hearing loss points to Vestibular Neuritis.
questions.hint: Viral inflammation of the balance nerve following a cold.

questions.question: A patient presents with a small, painless, well-defined nodule on the lateral aspect of the neck, just above the clavicle. Fine-needle aspiration cytology reveals clusters of polygonal cells with abundant granular cytoplasm. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: Ectopic parathyroid adenomas can be found in the neck. The cytology description ('polygonal cells with granular cytoplasm' - Oxyphil cells) matches parathyroid tissue.
questions.hint: Ectopic tissue responsible for calcium regulation.

questions.question: A patient presents with chronic nasal congestion, hyposmia, and anosmia. Nasal endoscopy reveals polypoid masses obstructing the nasal cavity and sinuses. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: The direct visualization of 'polypoid masses' confirms the diagnosis of Nasal Polyps. They are often associated with chronic inflammation.
questions.hint: Fleshy growths inside the nose causing obstruction.

questions.question: A patient presents with a unilateral, painless enlargement of the thyroid gland. Fine-needle aspiration cytology reveals numerous microfollicles and psammoma bodies. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: Psammoma bodies (calcific laminations) are a classic pathological hallmark of Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma.
questions.hint: Psammoma bodies are the key diagnostic finding here.

questions.question: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of throat pain, odynophagia, and fever. Physical examination reveals tonsillar enlargement with yellow-white exudates and tender cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: This is the classic presentation of Streptococcal Pharyngitis ('Strep Throat'): fever, tonsillar exudates, and tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: Commonly known as 'Strep Throat'.

questions.question: A patient presents with a sensation of fullness and pressure in the left ear, along with hearing loss and occasional tinnitus. Otoscopic examination reveals a retracted tympanic membrane with decreased mobility on pneumatic otoscopy. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?

options.text: Serous otitis media (otitis media with effusion)

questions.explanation: A retracted, immobile TM with fullness and hearing loss, but without signs of acute infection (fever, pain, bulging), indicates fluid behind the ear (Serous Otitis Media).
questions.hint: Fluid is present, but acute infection is not.

questions.question: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of sudden, severe vertigo lasting hours, accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and nystagmus. Vestibular function tests demonstrate unilateral weakness. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: The duration of vertigo (hours) distinguishes Ménière's from BPPV (seconds). Ménière's is the classic recurrent episodic vertigo lasting 20 min to hours.
questions.hint: Episodes last for hours, unlike the seconds-long episodes of BPPV.

questions.question: A patient presents with a sensation of a foreign body stuck in the throat, difficulty swallowing, and odynophagia. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals a submucosal mass arising from the posterior pharyngeal wall. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: A 'mass arising from the posterior pharyngeal wall' causing dysphagia and odynophagia is highly suspicious for malignancy.
questions.hint: A painful, obstructing mass in the throat suggests malignancy.

questions.question: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of postnasal drip, chronic cough, and halitosis. Nasal endoscopy reveals a foul-smelling, yellowish discharge draining from the middle meatus. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: Purulent (yellowish/foul) discharge from the middle meatus is the hallmark of Chronic Sinusitis.
questions.hint: The foul smell and drainage location point to a sinus infection.

questions.question: A patient presents with unilateral facial paralysis, inability to close the eye on the affected side, and loss of taste sensation on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: Bell's Palsy involves the Facial Nerve (CN VII). The symptoms described (motor paralysis, Chorda Tympani involvement causing taste loss) match the specific deficits of CN VII injury.
questions.hint: Idiopathic paralysis of Cranial Nerve VII.

questions.question: A patient presents with a painless, slowly enlarging mass in the right neck, just above the clavicle. Fine-needle aspiration cytology reveals clusters of polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm and centrally located nuclei. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: 'Clear cytoplasm' can refer to 'Water-clear cells' seen in parathyroid hyperplasia/adenoma. Ectopic Parathyroid Adenoma is the intended answer matching the histology.
questions.hint: Similar to a previous question regarding ectopic neck masses.

questions.question: A patient presents with sudden onset of severe vertigo, nausea, vomiting, and nystagmus. The patient reports a recent upper respiratory tract infection. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: The link to a recent viral infection is the key differentiator for Vestibular Neuritis.
questions.hint: Repeated concept: Vertigo after a viral infection.

questions.question: A patient presents with a small, painless, well-defined nodule on the lateral aspect of the neck, just above the clavicle. Fine-needle aspiration cytology reveals clusters of polygonal cells with abundant granular cytoplasm. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: Granular cytoplasm (Oxyphil cells) typically indicates parathyroid tissue, suggesting an ectopic adenoma.
questions.hint: Repeated concept: Granular cells in an ectopic neck mass.

questions.question: A patient presents with chronic nasal congestion, hyposmia, and anosmia. Nasal endoscopy reveals polypoid masses obstructing the nasal cavity and sinuses. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: Direct visualization of polyps confirms the diagnosis.
questions.hint: Repeated concept: Fleshy obstructive masses.

questions.question: A patient presents with a sensation of fullness and pressure in the left ear, along with hearing loss and occasional tinnitus. Otoscopic examination reveals a retracted tympanic membrane with decreased mobility on pneumatic otoscopy. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?

options.text: Serous otitis media (otitis media with effusion)

questions.explanation: Fluid behind the ear without acute infection causes pressure and retraction.
questions.hint: Repeated concept: Non-infected fluid in the middle ear.

questions.question: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of sudden, severe vertigo lasting hours, accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and nystagmus. Vestibular function tests demonstrate unilateral weakness. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation: Recurrent episodic vertigo lasting hours is characteristic of Ménière's.
questions.hint: Repeated concept: Recurrent vertigo of significant duration.
